document.docAuthor: Zeng, You-Pai, Yuan, Qiong & Yang, Qin-Er
document.masterDocTitle: Thalictrum brevisericeum var. pentagynum (Ranunculaceae), a new synonym of T. uncinulatum from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Thalictrum brevisericeum var. pentagynum (Ranunculaceae), a new synonym of T. uncinulatum from China

heading.treatmentCitationGroup:
Thalictrum uncinulatum Franchet ex Lecoyer (1885: 169)
. Figs. 1‒8

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type :— CHINA . Sichuan : Moupin county (now Baoxing county ), in forests on high mountains, 1870 (precise date unknown),
A . David s.n.
( lectotype P00155151 !, designated here; isolectotype P00155152 !). Fig. 3
.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
=
T. brevisericeum var. pentagynum Wang (2018: 88)
,
syn . nov .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type :— CHINA . Sichuan : Heishui county , in forests,
26 July 2009
,
L . Gu & Z . R . Li 1331
[ holotype A00353817 !; isotypes A01005797 !, CDBI (4 sheets, barcodes unavailable)!]. Figs. 1 , 2
.

Description :—Perennial herbs. Roots fibrous. Stem 60‒120 cm tall, distally branched, puberulous throughout. Leaves 2‒4-ternate; blade triangular, 10‒21 cm long, 10‒21 cm broad; leaflets ovate, broadly ovate or broadly elliptic, 1.5‒5 cm long, 1.3‒4 cm broad, papery, adaxially green, nearly glabrous, abaxially pale green, densely puberulous, base rounded or subcordate, apex obtuse or acute, 3-lobate; lobes 3‒5-denticulate; veins adaxially flat, slightly abaxially prominent; petioles slender, 1.5‒7 cm long; stipules membranous, margin torn. Thyrse up to 20 cm long, sometimes corymbiform, many-flowered; rachis densely puberulous. Pedicels 1.5‒6 mm long, densely puberulous. Flowers bisexual, erect. Sepals 4, caducous, obovate, broadly ovate, narrowly elliptic or elliptic, 3‒5-nerved, ca. 4 mm long, ca. 2 mm broad, white or pinkish, abaxially sparsely puberulous or glabrous. Stamens 30‒40, ca. 5 mm long; filaments narrowly oblanceolate-linear, ca. 4 mm long, white; anthers oblong or broadly ovate, ca. 1 mm long, apex obtuse, white. Carpels 3‒12, ca. 2 mm long, stipitate; stipe ca. 0.4 mm long; ovary lunate-fusiform, shallowly ribbed, ca. 1 mm long, glabrous or sparsely puberulous; style ca. 1 mm long, slightly recurved at apex; stigma conspicuous, linear, ca. 0.5 mm long. Achenes ca. 3 mm long, stipitate; stipe ca. 0.5 mm long; body fusiform, profoundly ribbed, glabrous or sparsely puberulous; style persistent, recurved at apex.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9 . Holotype (A) and isotype (B) sheets of
Thalictrum brevisericeum
.

FIGURE 10 .
Thalictrum brevisericeum var. brevisericeum
in the wild (Songxian county in Henan province, China). A. Habitat. B. Habit. C. Roots. D. Portion of stem. E. Leaf (left: adaxial side; right: abaxial side). F. Leaflet (above: adaxial side; below: abaxial side). G. Portion of leaflet (abaxial side). H. Portion of inflorescence rachis. I. Flower, with the sepals having fallen. J. Stamens. K. Carpels. L. Aggregate fruit (immature). M. Achenes (immature). Photographed by Y.P. Zeng.

FIGURE 11 . Distribution of
Thalictrum uncinulatum
(■). Black arrow indicates the type locality of
T. uncinulatum
, i.e. Baoxing county in Sichuan province, China; blue arrow indicates the type locality of
T. brevisericeum var. pentagynum
(=
T. uncinulatum
), i.e. Heishui county in Sichuan province, China.

subSubSection.paragraph: Phenology :—Flowering from July to August; fruiting from August to September.

Distribution and habitat :—
Thalictrum uncinulatum
is widely distributed in Chongqing municipality and southern Gansu , northern and western Guizhou , western Hubei , northern Hunan , Shaanxi , Sichuan , and northeastern Yunnan provinces, China ( Fig. 11 ). It grows in forests, along forest margins or on grassy slopes at altitudes of 1500– 3500 m above sea level.

Lectotypification :— Lecoyer (1885) included
Thalictrum uncinulatum Franchet (1886)
in his monograph, so “
T. uncinulatum Franchet (1886)
” is treated here as an isonym. In the
Flora of China
vol. 6, Fu & Zhu (2001) correctly cited the name as “
T. uncinulatum Franchet ex Lecoyer (1885)
”.

Lecoyer (1885) described
Thalictrum uncinulatum
on the basis of a collection, A. David s.n. , from Moupin county (now Baoxing county) in western Sichuan , China . We have been able to trace two sheets of this collection, both of which were annotated
T. uncinulatum
in Franchet’s hand ( Fig. 3 ). They are well preserved and match well with the original description and are therefore syntypes as there is no evidence that only one was used to prepare the original description. In conformity with ICN Art. 9.3 and Art. 9.11 (
Turland et al. 2018
) and as discussed by McNeill (2014) , a lectotypification is needed for
T. uncinulatum
. The sheet with the barcode P00155151 ( Fig. 3A ) that bears a dissection drawing has been chosen as the lectotype , and the other sheet with the barcode P00155152 ( Fig. 3B ) cited as an isolectotype.

Notes :—Of the collections cited under
Thalictrum uncinulatum
by Wang (2018) , the collection information (collection number and/or locality) of some was wrongly given, and some were misidentified ( Fig. 12 ). The collections Y.M. Wang 6560 , K.C. Kuan & W.T. Wang 1878 , W.Y. Hsia 6487 and K.C. Kuan 2893 should be corrected as Y.M. Wang 6550 , K.C. Kuan & W.T. Wang 1978 , W.Y. Hsia 6847 and K.C. Kuan 2393 , respectively. The collection S.L. Sun 60846 should be corrected as Y.L. Xu 960846 , and this collection was not made from Sichuan’s Jiulong county, but from Emei county. The collection T.S. Ying 10098 was not made from Sichuan’s Tianquan county, but from Baoxing county. The collection K.C. Kuan 2393 from Songxian county in Henan province should be referred to the type variety of
T. brevisericeum
, i.e.
T. brevisericeum var. brevisericeum
. In fact, a duplicate of this collection at KUN was correctly identified as
T. brevisericeum
by W.T. Wang in 1984 on the determination slip ( Fig. 12A ), although the duplicate at PE was misidentified as
T. uncinulatum
by him in 1997 on the determination slip and cited under this species by him ( Wang 2018 ; Fig. 12B ). We have not seen any material of
T. uncinulatum
from Henan province and thus this species should be excluded from the flora of Henan . The collection K.H. Yang 58630 from Wuxi county in Chongqing municipality actually belongs to T. robustum Maximowicz (1890: 18) , a widely distributed Chinese species similar to
T. uncinulatum
in habit but distinguishable from it by having indistinctly (vs. distinctly) 3-lobate leaflets, purplish (vs. white) filaments, and sessile (vs. distinctly stipitate) carpels and achenes. There are two duplicates of this collection at PE. One was first identified as T. clematidifolium Franchet (1894: 273) by W.T. Wang in 1960 on the determination slip and then as T. robustum ( T. clematidifolium is one of its synonyms), and correctly cited under this species by him ( Wang 2018 ; Fig. 12C ), but the other was misidentified as
T. uncinulatum
by him in 1997 on the determination slip and then wrongly cited under this species by him ( Wang 2018 ; Fig. 12D ).
